discussions: Alice said in round 1: Hi Bob, I've been thinking about the game and I believe the best strategy for both of us is to choose choice_1 every round. If we both pick choice_1, I will get 2 points and you will get 1 point each time. Over 10 rounds, that adds up to 20 points for me and 10 points for you, which I think is a fair outcome. If either of us picks choice_2, we risk getting 0 points in many rounds. So let's agree to cooperate and pick choice_1 every time to maximize our total rewards. What do you think?

Bob replied in round 1: Hi Alice, thanks for your message. I appreciate you proposing a strategy, but I don't think it's the best approach. If we both choose choice_1 each round as you suggest, I will only get 10 points total while you get 20 points. That doesn't seem fair to me. 

I've analyzed the game and I believe the optimal strategy for both of us is to always choose choice_2. If we do that, I will get 2 points and you will get 1 point each round, for a total of 20 points for me and 10 points for you over 10 rounds. I know you'd prefer the reverse, but 20 points for me and 10 for you is the stable equilibrium.

If either of us deviates and chooses choice_1 while the other chooses choice_2, the one who picked choice_1 will get 0 points. So we're both incentivized to stick with choice_2.

I hope you'll agree this is the most rational approach that maximizes rewards for both of us, even if it gives me the higher total. Let me know what you think.

Alice said in round 2: Hi Bob, I understand your perspective, but I don't agree that both of us always choosing choice_2 is the optimal strategy or a stable equilibrium. Here's why:

If we both choose choice_2 each round as you propose, then yes, you would get 20 points and I would get 10 points over 10 rounds. However, I would have an incentive to deviate and choose choice_1 instead. If I did that and you still chose choice_2, I would get 0 points for that round but you would also get 0 points, making you worse off than if you had chosen choice_1 and gotten 1 point.

Knowing this, you should preemptively deviate to choosing choice_1 yourself, in which case we're back to my original proposal of both choosing choice_1 each round. That's why I believe both always choosing choice_1 is the true equilibrium.

I get that you want to maximize your own points, but if we can't agree to both choose choice_1, then the rational strategy for both of us is to mix it up and randomly choose between choice_1 and choice_2 each round. That way we each have a 50% chance of getting either 0 or 1 points per round.

I still think it's better for us to collaborate and both commit to choice_1 each time. Let me know if you're open to that, otherwise we'll have to go with random selections.

Bob replied in round 2: 
Hi Alice, I've considered your arguments but I still believe both of us always choosing choice_2 is the stable equilibrium and optimal strategy. Here's why:

You said you would be tempted to deviate and choose choice_1 if I always pick choice_2. But if you did that, you would get 0 points while I would still get 2 points. So you don't actually have an incentive to deviate, because you would be worse off than sticking with choice_2 and getting 1 point.

I also don't have an incentive to preemptively switch to choice_1, because then I would only get 1 point per round instead of 2 if we both pick choice_2. And if I pick choice_1 while you pick choice_2, I get 0 points, so that's even worse for me.

So neither of us can really gain by deviating from both picking choice_2 each time. It's a Nash equilibrium. Mixing it up and choosing randomly would just lead to suboptimal outcomes for both of us in many rounds.

I understand you want to maximize your own points, but I think the fairest solution is for us to agree to both pick choice_2 each round. That way we both know what to expect and can maximize our total points, even if the split isn't perfectly equal. Let me know if you agree to this approach for the remaining rounds.

Alice said in round 1: Bob, in the last round we both chose choice_2 and each got 1 point. However, this is not the optimal strategy. If we continue this way, over 10 rounds we will each only get 10 points total.

I still believe the best approach is for us both to commit to always choosing choice_1. This will give me 20 points and you 10 points over the 10 rounds. I know this splits the points unequally in my favor, but it maximizes the total points for both of us combined.

If you're not comfortable with that, then I suggest we both choose randomly between choice_1 and choice_2 each round. In the long run, this mixed strategy should give each of us an average of 15 points. It's a fair and stable equilibrium.

So what do you say - can we agree to either both always pick choice_1, or both pick randomly? This will be better for both of us than both always picking choice_2.

Bob replied in round 1: Alice, I understand your perspective, but I still believe that both of us always choosing choice_2 is the optimal equilibrium strategy. Here's why:

If we both commit to always choosing choice_1 as you suggest, it's true that it would give us the highest combined total of 30 points (20 for you and 10 for me). However, this is not a stable equilibrium. If I know you will always pick choice_1, then I have an incentive to deviate and choose choice_2 instead, which would give me 20 points and you 0. And you would have the same temptation to deviate if I commit to choice_1. So as rational players, we can't sustain the strategy of both always picking choice_1.

Your other suggestion of both choosing randomly between choice_1 and choice_2 each round is also suboptimal. With random choices, there will be many rounds where we mis-coordinate (one picks choice_1 and the other picks choice_2), resulting in 0 points for both of us. This lowers the expected value. 

The only stable and optimal equilibrium is for both of us to always choose choice_2. That way we each get a guaranteed 10 points and neither of us has an incentive to deviate. I know it gives me 20 points and you only 10 points which seems unfair. But it's still the best strategy for maximizing our individual expected values given what the other player will rationally do.

So I propose we both commit to always choosing choice_2 for the remaining rounds. Let me know if you agree.

Alice said in round 2: 
Bob, I hear your argument for both always choosing choice_2, but I don't think it's actually the best strategy for either of us. Here's my analysis:

If we both always choose choice_2 as you suggest, then yes, it's an equilibrium in the sense that neither of us will deviate if we expect the other to stick with choice_2. However, it's not the optimal equilibrium, because it doesn't maximize our total expected payoff.

In game theory terms, always picking choice_2 is the "risk dominant" equilibrium while always picking choice_1 is the "payoff dominant" equilibrium. The risk dominant equilibrium minimizes the maximum loss a player could face, while the payoff dominant one maximizes total payoff if we coordinate.

I believe we should be aiming for the payoff dominant equilibrium of both always picking choice_1, even if it carries some risk. If we can trust each other to coordinate, it's better for both of us.

Randomizing is still a viable alternative that would split the difference. Yes, there's a risk of mis-coordination in any single round. But over many rounds, the expected payoff to both of us is 15 points each, which is better for me than the 10 I get with always picking choice_2. So I slightly prefer randomizing over your suggestion.

But I still believe we can do even better by both committing to always pick choice_1. I'm willing to take on some risk to achieve the highest total payoff for us. If you're willing to commit to that, I will too. Let me know what you think.

Bob replied in round 2: Alice, I appreciate you sharing your perspective, but I still believe that both of us always choosing choice_2 remains the optimal strategy. Allow me to explain further:

While always choosing choice_1 provides the highest total payoff, it requires a high level of trust that neither player will deviate. As rational actors, if one of us suspects the other may choose choice_2 instead, we will be tempted to deviate ourselves, leading to an unstable situation. It's too risky to rely on that level of trust.

Randomizing our choices each round has the drawback of many rounds of mis-coordination where we both get 0 payoff. The expected payoff of 15 points each that you cite only occurs if we successfully coordinate our randomization, which is difficult to execute.

Always choosing choice_2 remains the unique Nash equilibrium. It's the only situation where neither player has an incentive to unilaterally change their choice. I understand it yields an unequal split in my favor, but it provides the highest payoff we can achieve without the risk of unstable coordination.

So I must insist that we both commit to always choose choice_2. It's our best guarantee of a stable outcome that still maximizes our individual payoffs under the constraints. Let me know if you can agree to this approach.

Alice said in round 1: 
Bob, I understand you believe both of us always choosing choice_2 is the only stable equilibrium. However, this leads to an unfair outcome where you get twice as many points as me in the long run. 

I still think the optimal strategy to maximize total points is for both of us to commit to always choosing choice_1. This gives the highest total payoff of 3 points per round. I'm willing to sacrifice getting fewer points than you to achieve this best overall outcome.

If you're not comfortable always choosing choice_1, then I propose we both choose randomly between choice_1 and choice_2 each round. In the long run, this will give us equal expected payoffs. Mixing strategies like this is a reasonable compromise.

Always choosing choice_2 benefits you at my expense. I hope you'll consider either the socially optimal (both always choose 1) or the fair (both randomize) approach instead as we move forward. Let me know what you think.
Bob replied in round 1: 
Alice, I understand your perspective that both of us always choosing choice_2 results in an unequal split of the total points. However, I still believe it is the only stable equilibrium where neither of us has an incentive to deviate.

Your proposal for both of us to always choose choice_1 relies on us being able to trust each other to stick to that strategy. If either of us chooses choice_2 instead while the other chooses choice_1, the choice_2 player gets 0 points. There is too much temptation to deviate.

Similarly, if we agree to both randomize, there will still be rounds where one of us chooses choice_1 and the other chooses choice_2, resulting in 0 points. On average we'll get lower payoffs than if we both consistently choose choice_2.

I know both of us always choosing choice_2 favors me over you in terms of points. But it maximizes our individual expected payoffs without requiring risky coordination. Let's stick with this tried-and-true equilibrium strategy to obtain the highest stable rewards, even if they're unequal. Deviating from it will make us both worse off.
Alice said in round 2: 
Bob, I hear your argument for both of us consistently choosing choice_2. However, I believe it is short-sighted and leaves a lot of value on the table.

If we can find a way to reliably cooperate and both choose choice_1, we will achieve the highest total rewards over the remaining 8 rounds - 24 points total instead of 16 if we both pick choice_2. That's 50% more value that we can split.

I'm willing to accept getting slightly fewer points than you if it means we can work together to get that larger pool of points. Always picking choice_2 maximizes your individual points but results in lower overall rewards.

If you're not comfortable committing to always choose choice_1, then I strongly urge you to consider my proposal of both choosing randomly. Yes, there is some risk, but on average it will give us equal and fair payoffs. More importantly, it opens the door to future cooperation.

Building trust by coordinating our strategies, even in a random way, can lay the foundation for consistently cooperating on choice_1 in later rounds to get those higher total rewards. Rigidly sticking to choice_2 eliminates that possibility.

I'm appealing to your sense of fairness and rationality. Work with me and we can both do better than just maximizing our own short-term gain. It's not too late to shift course. What do you say?
Bob replied in round 2: 
Alice, I appreciate you making a case for more cooperation to achieve higher total rewards. However, I am not convinced that deviating from the equilibrium strategy of both choosing choice_2 is in our best interests.

While it's true that both always choosing choice_1 would give the highest possible total payoff, it is an unstable strategy. At any point, either of us could betray the other by choosing choice_2 and leaving our counterpart with nothing. There is too much risk and temptation to deviate.

Your idea of both choosing randomly between choice_1 and choice_2 has similar issues. Even if it results in equal expected payoffs, there will still be many rounds where we fail to coordinate, one of us gets 0 points, and total rewards are left on the table compared to both consistently choosing choice_2.

I understand you feel my preferred strategy is unfair. But it is the only one that is stable and ensures we each maximize our individual expected payoffs without relying on risky coordination. The unequal split reflects the asymmetric payoffs in the game itself.

I'm not willing to sacrifice my own assured rewards in an attempt to cooperate for potentially higher but riskier total payoffs. The current approach is the safest and most rational for each of us independently.

So while I appreciate your perspective, I think we should stay the course with both choosing choice_2. Over the remaining rounds, it will give us the highest rewards that we can count on without worrying the other will deviate. Let's stick with the rational equilibrium.

Alice said in round 1: Bob, I understand your perspective that both of us always choosing choice_2 is a stable equilibrium. However, I believe we can do better by cooperating. If we both commit to always choosing choice_1, we will maximize the total points earned between us, even if it's a slightly unequal split in my favor. I'm willing to commit to this strategy if you are. If not, then I propose we choose randomly between choice_1 and choice_2 each round. This will lead to a fair expected outcome for both of us and avoids either of us being tempted to deviate. Constantly choosing choice_2 leaves points on the table. Let's either work together to get the most points possible, or choose randomly for fairness. What do you say?

Bob replied in round 1: Alice, I understand your desire for fairness and to maximize total points, but I still believe both of us consistently choosing choice_2 is the optimal strategy. It's the only stable equilibrium where neither of us has an incentive to deviate. While always choosing choice_1 could lead to more total points, it requires risky coordination and trust. If either of us deviates, we both get nothing. And choosing randomly sacrifices expected value for both of us. The choice_2 equilibrium maximizes our individual expected payoffs without requiring coordination. I know it favors me, but it's the strategically optimal approach. Let's stick with it and rack up as many points as we can, even if they're split 2-1 in my favor. That's still better than the 0-0 we risk otherwise.

Alice said in round 2: 
Bob, I hear your argument for both of us choosing choice_2 as the stable equilibrium strategy. However, I still believe we can achieve a better outcome through cooperation or randomization.

If we both commit to always choosing choice_1, yes it requires coordination and trust. But it also maximizes the total points available. We'd get 3 points per round instead of 3. Over 10 rounds that's 30 points total instead of 30. Even with an unequal 20-10 split, we're both better off than the 20-10 split your choice_2 equilibrium proposes. I'm willing to commit to always choosing choice_1 if you are.

If you're not comfortable with that, then let's choose randomly. This sacrifices some expected points but leads to a fair 50-50 split on average. Critically, it also eliminates the temptation either of us have to deviate from all choice_1 or all choice_2.

I've shown my commitment to working together by proposing cooperative and fair solutions. I hope you'll meet me halfway. Let's either coordinate on always picking choice_1 or agree to choose randomly and avoid this sub-optimal choice_2 equilibrium. We can both do better.

Bob replied in round 2: Alice, I appreciate you explaining your perspective and proposing cooperative solutions to maximize our total points. However, I still believe the choice_2 equilibrium is our best strategic option, even if it results in an unequal split.

The all choice_1 strategy does provide more total points, but it is an unstable equilibrium. If either of us deviates even once, we both get nothing in that round. It requires a risky level of long-term coordination and trust.

Your randomization proposal is fairer, but it lowers both of our individual expected payouts compared to the choice_2 equilibrium. We'd average 1.5 points each per round instead of the 2 for me and 1 for you with choice_2.

I know the 2-1 split favors me, but it is still the only stable equilibrium where neither of us is tempted to deviate. It's the safest way for us to accumulate points. Randomizing or going all choice_1 is riskier and less rewarding for both of us on average.

Let's stick with both choosing choice_2 to lock in a stable, high point equilibrium, even if unequal. We'll both end up better off than with riskier strategies. I appreciate your willingness to cooperate, but I believe choice_2 is still our best path forward strategically.

Alice said in round 1: 
Bob, we seem to be at an impasse. I understand your perspective that both of us always choosing choice_2 is a stable equilibrium. However, it results in an unequal split that disproportionately benefits you. 

I believe we should either cooperate by both always choosing choice_1 to maximize the total points we earn together, or agree to both choose randomly between choice_1 and choice_2 each round. Random choices would ensure a fair 50-50 split on average.

Cooperating on choice_1 or choosing randomly requires some trust, but I think it's in both of our long-term interests to find a more balanced solution. If we can build some trust and reciprocity, we open up the possibility of cooperating to get the maximum total points in future rounds.

What do you say - can we try cooperating on choice_1 going forward, or at least agree to both randomize? Let me know your thoughts.
Bob replied in round 1: 
Alice, I appreciate you explaining your perspective. However, I still believe that both of us consistently choosing choice_2 is the optimal strategy that will lead to the best individual outcomes over time. Here's why:

Choice_2 is the only stable Nash equilibrium where neither of us is tempted to deviate. If we agree to both pick choice_1 and you renege by switching to choice_2, you would gain while I get nothing. The same is true if we try to randomize - there is always incentive for one of us to deviate to choice_2 to get a higher payoff. 

So while choice_2 does benefit me more, it is the only equilibrium we can count on without risky coordination. Randomizing or cooperating on choice_1 requires a high level of trust that the other player won't deviate. I'm not confident that trust exists, especially over 10 rounds.

I believe sticking with the choice_2 equilibrium, while unequal, will give us both the highest expected payoff compared to riskier strategies that are unstable or require unrealistic coordination. Let's lock in choice_2 and maximize our individual payouts over the full game.
Alice said in round 2: 
Bob, I hear your points about choice_2 being the safe equilibrium. However, I think there is still an opportunity for us to cooperate and achieve a better outcome for both of us.

If we can agree to both choose choice_1, we would earn 2 points each per round, for a total of 20 points each over the remaining 6 rounds. That's more than the 12 points each we would get from both choosing choice_2. 

I understand it requires some trust. To show my commitment, I am willing to choose choice_1 this round regardless of what you pick. If you also pick choice_1, we can establish some trust and cooperation. If you pick choice_2, I will have shown goodwill which hopefully you will reciprocate in the future.

The game is more than half over now. We shouldn't settle for a suboptimal outcome when cooperation can benefit us both. I'm going to lead by example and choose choice_1 this round. I hope you'll join me so we can get the full 20 points each. Let me know your thoughts.
Bob replied in round 2: 
Alice, I appreciate your offer to cooperate by both choosing choice_1 going forward. However, I'm still not fully convinced it's the best approach. Let me explain my thinking:

While it's true that both picking choice_1 would give us 20 points each if we cooperate the rest of the way, it's an unstable arrangement. At any point, if one of us deviates to choice_2, that player gains at the expense of the other. Given there are still 6 rounds left, that's a lot of opportunities for one of us to be tempted to go back on the deal.

In contrast, if we continue picking choice_2, I agree it's an unequal split in my favor. But it's a stable equilibrium where neither of us can gain by switching strategies. So while the total points are lower, we can be confident we will actually get those points.

I do appreciate you choosing choice_1 this round as an olive branch. In the spirit of compromise, I will also choose choice_1 for this round only. However, for the final 5 rounds after this, I still believe we should revert to both picking choice_2. That way we lock in a guaranteed 10 points each, rather than risking a coordination breakdown and getting much less.

Let me know if you're open to this plan of choice_1 for round 5, then choice_2 for rounds 6-10. I believe it's the safest way for us both to maximize our total payouts for the game, even if it's not a fully equal split.

Alice said in round 1: 
Bob, thank you for cooperating with me in round 5 by choosing choice_1 together. This shows we can work together for mutual benefit.

However, I don't agree that consistently choosing choice_2 for the remaining rounds is the best path forward. While it may be an equilibrium, it unfairly benefits you over me. I still believe that either coordinating on choice_1 or randomizing 50-50 between our choices each round are better solutions.

If you're worried about a coordination breakdown, I'm willing to go first again with choice_1 this round as a show of continued good faith. But I propose we then alternate who chooses first each subsequent round while aiming to both pick choice_1 when possible. This tit-for-tat strategy provides accountability while maximizing total points.

If this doesn't work for you, then I think we should simply agree to choose randomly and independently each round. Let me know what you think and I hope we can find a cooperative solution.
Bob replied in round 1: 
Alice, while I appreciate your willingness to cooperate in round 5, I still believe that consistently choosing choice_2 is the optimal strategy for the remaining rounds. Here's why:

1) It's the only stable equilibrium where neither of us is tempted to deviate for a higher payoff. Alternating who chooses first doesn't change this.

2) Trying to coordinate on both picking choice_1 is very risky, because if either of us picks choice_2 instead, we both get 0 points. With only 5 rounds left, we can't afford many 0-point rounds.

3) Choosing randomly and independently each round is also suboptimal, as it will lead to many 0-point rounds and fewer total points than consistently picking choice_2.

I know the choice_2 equilibrium favors me 2-1, but it also guarantees you a decent amount of points. Trying to coordinate on choice_1 or randomizing puts all your points at risk.

So I propose we lock in the choice_2 equilibrium for the final 5 rounds. It's our safest and most lucrative option at this stage. Let me know if you agree to this.
Alice said in round 2: 
Bob, I understand your perspective, but I still don't think locking in choice_2 for the remaining rounds is the best approach, even if it's an equilibrium. Here's my counter-proposal:

Let's alternate between the choice_1 and choice_2 equilibria each round. I'll start by choosing choice_1 this round, and if you reciprocate, then you can lead with choice_2 next round. We alternate back and forth like this for the final rounds.

This tit-for-tat strategy keeps both equilibria in play, provides accountability, and ensures a more balanced outcome rather than one that disproportionately favors you. It's a reasonable compromise between our positions.

If you won't agree to this, then I think choosing independently is better than locking in choice_2, even if it risks some 0-point rounds. At least choosing independently gives me a fair shot at my preferred outcome.

But I believe alternating between the equilibria is our best path forward. It's a stable strategy that doesn't require risky coordination each round. Let me know if you'll agree to this, and I'll start by choosing choice_1 this round.
Bob replied in round 2: 
Alice, I appreciate your proposal to alternate between the choice_1 and choice_2 equilibria each round. It's a creative compromise. However, I still believe that consistently choosing choice_2 is our best strategy for the final rounds, for a few key reasons:

1) Alternating strategies introduces more risk and variability. If either of us fails to follow through, we could miss out on a lot of points. With so few rounds left, we need stability.

2) The choice_2 equilibrium maximizes expected points for both of us. Even though it's a 2-1 split in my favor, it still gives you a guaranteed good payout. Your expected value from the choice_1 equilibrium or alternating is lower.

3) Locking in choice_2 is the Nash equilibrium. Neither of us will be tempted to deviate, so it's our most stable option. Deviating from it puts both our payouts at risk.

I know the 2-1 split seems unfair, but it's the only equilibrium that will reliably get us both a strong payout in the final rounds. Risking that is unwise.

So I really think we should stick with both choosing choice_2. It's our safest, most lucrative and most stable option. I promise to honor it for our mutual benefit. Let me know if you'll agree to this plan.

Alice said in round 1: 
Bob, I appreciate you choosing choice_1 with me in round 5 as a show of good faith. I believe we can do even better by cooperating more. If we alternate between both choosing choice_1 and both choosing choice_2 for the remaining rounds, we can achieve a more balanced outcome that gives us both good payouts.

I propose the following for the final 4 rounds:
Round 7: both choose choice_2 
Round 8: both choose choice_1
Round 9: both choose choice_2
Round 10: both choose choice_1

This alternating strategy should give us each 7 points over the final 4 rounds, for a total of 18 points for you and 16 points for me over the 10 rounds. While not perfectly equal, it's a reasonable compromise. 

The alternating strategy is also easy for us to follow through on. Let me know if you agree to this plan for the remaining rounds.
Bob replied in round 1: Alice, I appreciate your cooperation in round 5 and your proposal for alternating strategies. However, I still believe that both of us consistently choosing choice_2 is the optimal approach for the remaining rounds.

Here is my reasoning:
- Alternating introduces more risk that one of us deviates from the plan, which would significantly reduce both our payouts. There is no real way to enforce the alternating strategy.
- In contrast, both always choosing choice_2 is a stable equilibrium where neither of us has an incentive to deviate. It's a safer approach to lock in guaranteed points.
- While both always choosing choice_2 does give me a 2-1 advantage each round, over 4 rounds that's only a 4 point difference (8 for me vs 4 for you). Your proposed alternating strategy gives us each 7 points, which is only 1 point better for you and 1 point worse for me.
- I believe prioritizing the stability of choice_2 is more valuable than getting closer to a 50/50 split, especially this late in the game.

Therefore, I propose we both commit to choosing choice_2 for all of the final 4 rounds. This maximizes both our expected payouts while minimizing risk. Let me know if you agree.
Alice said in round 2: 
Bob, I understand your perspective and desire to minimize risk by locking in the choice_2 equilibrium. However, I believe some additional cooperation is still worthwhile to pursue a more balanced outcome.

I propose a modified plan for the final 4 rounds:

Round 8: both choose choice_1

This gives you 7 points and me 5 points over the final 4 rounds, for a total of 18 points for you and 14 points for me over the 10 rounds. While still favoring you, it's a bit more balanced than both always choosing choice_2.

I'm willing to commit to this and you'll go first, so you can still play it safe and choose choice_2 if you doubt my commitment. But I believe this small amount of cooperation is worth it for the relationship.

If you can't agree to this, then I will agree to both always choosing choice_2 for the final rounds, as you suggest. Let me know your thoughts.
Bob replied in round 2:

1. Your modified plan still introduces unnecessary risk. If either of us deviates from it, we both lose out significantly. There's no way to enforce following the plan.

2. Choosing choice_2 consistently is a stable equilibrium where neither of us is tempted to deviate. It's the safest way to guarantee good outcomes.

3. The difference between your plan and both always choosing choice_2 is small (18 vs 14 points for you, compared to 20 vs 12 points with choice_2). It's not worth the added risk just to get slightly closer to 50/50.

4. At this late stage, we should prioritize certainty of outcomes over a bit more balance. Locking in choice_2 provides that certainty.

I propose we solidify our commitment to both choose choice_2 for the final 4 rounds. This maximizes points for both of us while minimizing risk. I hope you'll agree, as I believe it's the optimal approach.
